<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_shrink_read_buffer:
```c
static void
connection_shrink_read_buffer (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  void *new_buf;

  if ((NULL == c->read_buffer) || (0 == c->read_buffer_size))
  {
    mhd_assert (0 == c->read_buffer_size);
    mhd_assert (0 == c->read_buffer_offset);
    return;
  }

  mhd_assert (c->read_buffer_offset <= c->read_buffer_size);
  if (0 == c->read_buffer_offset)
  {
    MHD_pool_deallocate (c->pool, c->read_buffer, c->read_buffer_size);
    c->read_buffer = NULL;
    c->read_buffer_size = 0;
  }
  else
  {
    mhd_assert (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (c->pool, c->read_buffer, \
                                               c->read_buffer_size));
    new_buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (c->pool, c->read_buffer, c->read_buffer_size,
                                   c->read_buffer_offset);
    mhd_assert (c->read_buffer == new_buf);
    c->read_buffer = new_buf;
    c->read_buffer_size = c->read_buffer_offset;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 17.8 forbids modifying the function parameter itself; it allows modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter. In this function there is no assignment to the parameter variable 'connection' (no "connection = ..." or similar). The local alias is declared as 'struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection;' so the local pointer is const and cannot be changed; all assignments in the body (c->read_buffer = NULL, c->read_buffer_size = 0, c->read_buffer = new_buf, c->read_buffer_size = c->read_buffer_offset) modify members of the pointed-to object, which is permitted by the rule. Calls that pass those members to pool functions only pass objects by value and do not modify the parameter variable. Therefore there are no fragments that violate Rule 17.8 and no further investigation of other fragments is required for this rule.
